intro: Abelmoschus manihot var. mindanaensis, commonly known as the Mindanao okra, is a variant of the okra species native to the Philippines. It is characterized by its thick, fibrous stems and large, heart-shaped leaves that are typically green with a slightly hairy texture. The plant produces capsule fruits that contain numerous seeds, which are dispersed by wind and animals. It thrives in tropical and subtropical climates, preferring well-drained soil and full sunlight. This variety is valued for its edible young fruits and its potential use in traditional medicine.
distribution_native_art_desc: Abelmoschus manihot var. mindanaensis is primarily native to the Philippines, particularly the island of Mindanao. It is commonly found in the lowland and mountainous regions of this area. This variant of the abelmoschus plant thrives in tropical and subtropical climates. It is often associated with moist and well-drained soils in its natural habitat. The plant is known for its use in traditional agriculture and local food systems in the region.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Abelmoschus manihot var. mindanaensis was mainly introduced to the Philippines. It is commonly found in the Mindanao region, where it thrives in tropical climates. This variant is known for its high starch content and is used for both food and industrial purposes. It has been cultivated by local communities for generations. Its introduction has contributed to the agricultural diversity of the area.
